record.author: Alan Jones, Barnabas Maua, Malcolm Ross
record.notes:
All stems functioning as finite verbs are preceded by a subject-marking clitic or prefix. In the third person (the usual citation form) this can be either e- or i-. The former marks the verb as irrealis while the latter is the characteristic form for narratives. I have chosen to represent all verbs with the irrealis e- form, for consistency.
All noun stems that may be inalienably possessed (body parts, relations, etc.) are represented with the 3rd person suffix marker -na, indexing a third person ""possessor"" - such stems, when used as adjectives, as a general rule take a person-marking suffix ; on some stems this has become fossilised, while others resist it (possibly only in some uses). Hyphenation indicates affixation; even the subject markers are represented here as prefixes, though the argument for this has yet to be made.
record.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, Papuan Tip, Peripheral, Central Papuan, West Central Papuan, Nuclear

record.annotation: Lit. his heart is pumping; also nua-na e-veli
k.o. grass or reeds: <g> doesn't occur in Kuni: error?
With a knife, e.g. a rope
Kava, price; kava-na e-beni, pay for.
be ashamed: lit. fau = forehead and tsia = bad
climb a ladder, climb a mountain
